title: The Importance of OTC Drug Safety

content: There are several over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers that help ease all sorts of pain and minor conditions. Despite not being narcotics, OTC pain relievers have certain risks, so you should use them safely to avoid side effects.

sections.heading: What Are the Most Common OTC Pain Relievers?
content: Acetaminophen (also called paracetamol ) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the two most common types of OTC pain relievers. NSAIDs include aspirin , ibuprofen , and naproxen . Each of these medicines can ease pain and lower fever, but not all of them work the same way. Acetaminophen works better for headaches or muscle aches. NSAIDs work better for pain caused by swelling and inflammation, such as muscle tears or herniated disks.

sections.heading: What Kind of Pain Do You Have?
content: There is acute pain and chronic pain. Acute pain can start suddenly and does not last long. Acute pain is completely relieved when the body heals. A stress headache that is relieved with an analgesic can be considered acute pain. Chronic pain lasts longer, sometimes several months, or years, or even for life. Back pain is a type of chronic pain.

sections.heading: Acetaminophen
content: You can use acetaminophen for acute pain or, if your doctor recommends it, for chronic pain. Keep the following points in mind: Taking more than the recommended dose can damage the liver or kidneys. Do not take acetaminophen together with other medicines that contain acetaminophen. Do not take acetaminophen if you drink three or more alcoholic beverages a day because it can damage the liver. Do not take acetaminophen if you have liver disease because it can cause even more liver damage, even if you take the right dose. You may be able to take acetaminophen short-term during pregnancy , but it’s important to talk to your doctor before doing so. You can take acetaminophen for certain types of chronic pain if it’s part of the treatment plan your doctor recommended and only as directed.

content: Follows these tips: Do not take high doses of any NSAIDs because they can cause kidney problems and fluid retention. Do not take any NSAIDs together with other medicines that contain an NSAID. Do not take any NSAIDs if you have advanced kidney disease, stomach ulcers, or severe heart failure. Do not take any NSAIDs during the third trimester of pregnancy. Do not take aspirin at any point during pregnancy. Do not take NSAIDs if you are taking certain cancer drugs that could cause bleeding or if you are taking blood thinners, steroids, or high blood pressure medicine. Taking one low-dose aspirin a day can lower the risk of having a heart attack or stroke. However, talk to your doctor before you start taking it on a regular basis. Daily use of aspirin can have serious side effects, such as bleeding in the stomach. Aspirin has also been linked to Reye syndrome, a rare but serious condition that causes swelling in the brain and liver. Doctors recommend children and adolescents younger than 18 years who are recovering from chickenpox or flu -like symptoms or any viral diseases never take aspirin.

sections.heading: Always Read the Label and Take the Correct Dose
content: The label contains information about the dose you need to take and the active and inactive ingredients. If you are taking any other pain medicine, you should compare the active ingredients to make sure they are not the same. Remember that taking a very high dose of anything can cause serious harm.

sections.heading: Store Medicines in a Dry and Safe Place
content: Prescription and OTC medicines can lose their effectiveness before their expiration date if you keep them in a hot or humid place. That’s why you should never store any medicine in the bathroom cabinet or in direct sunlight. Always store medicines in a dry, safe place, out of the reach of pets and children.

sections.heading: Safely Dispose of Medicines
content: You can throw away OTC medicines in the garbage. Remove the medicine from its original packaging and put it into a plastic bag. Add used ground coffee or kitty litter and mix it so you can’t see the medicine. Seal the bag so it’s airtight and throw it and the empty packaging away. If you have any questions about how to get rid of expired or damaged medicines, talk to your pharmacist.

sections.heading: When Should You Call Your Doctor?
content: Call your doctor if after a few days of taking OTC pain relievers: You still feel pain. The pain feels worse. The pain doesn’t let you sleep. You feel anxiety about having pain constantly.
